image.altText: A collage of black and white images of a man smiling in a suit and tie, holding a rifle, and in a passport-style photo.

items.synopsis: The untold spy story of a mole in ASIO's ranks who sold the Soviets highly classified intelligence and got away with it.

title.children: 'This guy flew under the radar': The mole embedded in the heart of Australia's spy agency

image.altText: A composite image of two men and a woman, separated by paper tears.

items.synopsis: Across Australia, more than 46,000 clients under state control are prevented by law from being identified, but there are growing calls for change. Some say gag laws that were designed to protect vulnerable people are shielding these agencies from scrutiny.

title.children: Once silenced by the state, now Uli, Fran and Peter are speaking out

image.altText: A woman holding a baby and a hockey stick.

items.synopsis: Finding an appropriate healthcare professional to help manage an athlete's return to sport postpartum can be tricky, particularly at an amateur level.

title.children: Jessica needed help preparing her postpartum body for a return to hockey. Finding that help wasn't easy

image.altText: Three people stand in blizzard at Mount Hotham.

items.synopsis: A polar air mass sends the mercury plunging over south-eastern Australia on Tuesday and Wednesday, while a thick rain band is brewing in the north-west and set to deliver falls across the country by the end of the week.

title.children: South-eastern Australia to shiver through prolonged frosty weather, with 'tropical' rain on the way

image.altText: Composite of three photos showing progression of baby Jarrod's illness. Baby gets more pale and has red rash aroujd his mouth

items.synopsis: Baby Jarrod was in "absolute agony" when his parents took him to the emergency department two days in a row. He only received a diagnosis when his father called in Ryan's Rule.

title.children: 'We dropped the ball': Hospital boss apologises for failing to admit baby with potentially fatal infection

image.altText: Pat Cummins clenches fists and yells in delight as Ben Stokes walks off behind him

items.synopsis: Australia has raised eyebrows with its anti-Bazball measures in the first Ashes Test at Edgbaston, but all the spread fields and conservative bowling could yet add up to a famous win.

title.children: Australia and England follow different paths to meet for a thrilling climax to Edgbaston Test

image.altText: Steve Smith rolls on the ground

items.synopsis: England started day four of the first Ashes Test with a wild reverse ramp from Joe Root, and never looked back on a thrilling day of Test cricket. Here's the five things you missed overnight.

title.children: Five quick hits — Root's unorthodox batting raises eyebrows and Bairstow lets Khawaja off

image.altText: A middle-aged man in jeans and a jacket sits in a chair and smiles. In front is a table with Titanic Expedition written on it

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Wealthy businessman missing on Titanic explorer, and Putin critic Navalny's new trial begins. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You may have already heard about the rescue effort which is underway after a Titanic tourist submersible went missing. The family of British businessman Hamish Harding has confirmed that he is one of the people onboard. His stepson wrote on Facebook that Harding has "gone missing on submarine", and asked for "thoughts and prayers" —before subsequently removing the post, citing respect for the family's privacy. Harding himself had posted on social media a day earlier that he would be aboard the sub, and there have been no posts from him since. Harding is Chairman of Action Aviation, an international company which deals with sales and operations in the business aviation industry. Harding was a passenger on the fifth commercial flight of Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos's space firm, and also holds a few Guinness World Records for his explorative travels.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: British businessman Hamish Harding is on the missing Titanic tourist vessel

props.alt: A middle-aged man sitting in a chair with his legs crossed, and smiling

children.content: (Facebook: Hamish Harding)
You may have already heard about the rescue effort which is underway after a Titanic tourist submersible went missing.
The family of British businessman
Hamish Harding
has confirmed that he is one of the people onboard.
His stepson wrote on Facebook that Harding has "gone missing on submarine", and asked for "thoughts and prayers" —before subsequently removing the post, citing respect for the family's privacy.
Harding himself had posted on social media a day earlier that he would be aboard the sub, and there have been no posts from him since.
Harding is
Chairman of Action Aviation
, an international company which deals with sales and operations in the business aviation industry.
Harding
was a passenger on the fifth commercial flight of Blue Origin
, Jeff Bezos's space firm, and also
holds a few Guinness World Records
for his explorative travels.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Imprisoned Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny is urging his supporters to begin a broad campaign against Moscow's actions in Ukraine, as he goes on trial on new charges of extremism which could keep him behind bars for decades. The trial began inside a maximum security penal colony in Melekhovo, where 47-year-old Navalny is serving a nine-year sentence for fraud and contempt of court — charges which he says are politically motivated. Soon after it started, the judge closed the trial despite Navalny's demand to keep it open. Navalny says his new extremism charges, which he rejects as "absurd," could keep him in prison for another 30 years. He says an investigator told him that he would also face a separate military trial on terrorism charges that potentially carry a life sentence. "We must do what they fear — tell the truth, spread the truth," Navalny says. "This is the most powerful weapon against this regime of liars, thieves and hypocrites. Everyone has this weapon. So make use of it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny begins new trial on 'absurd' extremism charges

props.alt: A view of a TV Screen showing Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, 2nd left, between his lawyers in a courtroom

children.content: (AP: Alexander Zemlianichenko)
Imprisoned Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny is urging his supporters to begin a broad campaign against Moscow's actions in Ukraine, as he
goes on trial on new charges of extremism
which could keep him behind bars for decades.

The trial began inside a maximum security penal colony in Melekhovo, where 47-year-old Navalny is serving a nine-year sentence for fraud and contempt of court — charges which he says are politically motivated.
Soon after it started, the judge closed the trial
despite Navalny's demand to keep it open.
Navalny says his new extremism charges, which he rejects as "absurd," could keep him in prison for another 30 years.
He says an investigator told him that he would also face a separate military trial on terrorism charges that potentially carry a life sentence.
"We must do what they fear — tell the truth, spread the truth," Navalny says.
"This is the most powerful weapon against this regime of liars, thieves and hypocrites. Everyone has this weapon. So make use of it."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've ever been to Rome, you might remember seeing a section of ancient temples which were overrun by stray cats, but not open to the public. Welll, those temples, which date back as far as the 3rd century BC, can now be visited by tourists. For decades, the curious had to gaze down from the bustling sidewalks rimming Largo Argentina (Argentina Square) to admire the temples below. That's because, over the centuries, the city had been built up, layer by layer, to levels several meters above the area where Caesar masterminded his political strategies and was later fatally stabbed in 44 BC. Behind two of the temples is a foundation and part of a wall that archaeologists believe were part of Pompey's Curia, a large rectangular-shaped hall that temporarily hosted the Roman Senate when Caesar was murdered. I do hope the cats can still hang out there though.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One more thing: These four ancient Roman temples are now open to tourists

props.alt: People walking among ancient Roman ruins

children.content: (AP: Domenico Stinellis)
If you've ever been to Rome, you might remember seeing a section of ancient temples which were overrun by stray cats, but not open to the public.
Welll, those temples, which date back as far as the 3rd century BC,
can now be visited by tourists
For decades, the curious had to gaze down from the bustling sidewalks rimming
Largo Argentina (Argentina Square)
to admire the temples below.

That's because, over the centuries, the city had been built up, layer by layer, to levels several meters above the area where Caesar masterminded his political strategies and was later fatally stabbed in 44 BC.

Behind two of the temples is a foundation and part of a wall that archaeologists believe were part of Pompey's Curia, a large rectangular-shaped hall that temporarily hosted the Roman Senate when Caesar was murdered.
I do hope the cats can still hang out there though.

props.alt: People walking among ancient Roman ruins

image.altText: A small submersible plunging into the water.

items.synopsis: A search is underway for a submersible craft that is missing near the wreck of the Titanic.

title.children: Rescue efforts underway after Titanic tourist submersible goes missing

image.altText: Putin says he may seize 'buffer zone' in Ukraine

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin has a brutal new strategy to ensure Russia's invasion of Ukraine is "a long process". It means there are now strategic and humanitarian imperatives for the West to defeat Putin's latest theory of victory, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Why Vladimir Putin is hoping for a long war in Ukraine

image.altText: Women in black shirt holding flyer looks sad

items.synopsis: Carrie-Ann Adams's symptoms were mistaken for the flu — but in reality, she was dying of bowel cancer and had 12 weeks to live.

title.children: Ann says lowering the bowel cancer screening age could have saved her 41yo daughter's life

image.altText: Bill Shorten

items.synopsis: The actions of Australia's politicians in parliament come under fire on Q+A after a week that saw David Van leave the Liberals and Katy Gallagher grilled by the Coalition.

title.children: 'Toxic': Shorten takes aim at behaviour of politicians in parliament

image.altText: A clothing store in Sydney advertises for staff in its shopfront.

items.synopsis: While economic growth is slowing, the jobs market hasn't been this strong since the 1950s. Unemployment is plumbing half century lows — a development that has everyone from central banks to politicians scratching their heads, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Can record low unemployment pull us through a recession?

image.altText: Greg Pickhaver

items.synopsis: He's one half of much-loved comedy duo Roy and HG, but Greig Pickhaver says a diagnosis of dyslexia was both a "blessing and a curse" as he carved out a successful career "making up things on the spot".

title.children: Greig 'HG Nelson' Pickhaver on the 'blessing and curse' of his dyslexia

image.altText: A white woman with grey hair and blue eyes looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: Set amid the sexism of the 60s, Lessons in Chemistry and its fiery protagonist have captured hearts around the world.

title.children: Bonnie Garmus was sick of being belittled by men. So she wrote herself a role model

image.altText: Ollie Robinson holds his arms out in celebration as Joe Root runs towards him

items.synopsis: Late wickets help England gain the upper hand of an enthralling first Ashes Test at Edgbaston, with Australia needing 174 more runs to win with seven wickets remaining.

title.children: Australia's night watchman makes it through late day-four flurry, setting up thrilling finale to first Ashes Test

image.altText: A Ukrainian soldier covers his ears as he fires a mortar at Russian positions next to a burnt out car.

items.synopsis: British military officials say both Russia and Ukraine are suffering high numbers of casualties as Kyiv fights to dislodge the Kremlin's forces from occupied areas.

title.children: Ukraine, Russia suffering heavy casualties during Kyiv's counteroffensive, UK assessment says

image.altText: head of a shimmering blue fish against a black background

items.synopsis: Fish around the world have declined in size as water temperatures warm, but the reason why is poorly understood. Our experiments offer some clues as we prepare for a warmer future with smaller fish.

title.children: The world's fish are getting smaller. We're trying to figure out why

image.altText: Man in suit stands in front of tree smiling at camera.

items.synopsis: Victorian councillors want more training for those new to local government ahead of the 2024 elections, with one suggesting more thorough background checks.

title.children: Councillor says election process is too easy amid calls for more governance training

image.altText: Fire crews stand in front of an overturned bus beside a road.

items.synopsis: The bride and groom whose wedding ended in tragedy when a bus carrying guests tipped in the NSW Hunter say they are trying to process the disaster.

title.children: Newlyweds release statement after Hunter Valley bus crash

image.altText: A man speaking on a podium

items.synopsis: For the first time, the Australian government will sponsor a poet to represent the country, but the details of how they will be selected remain a mystery.

title.children: Australia will choose its first-ever poet laureate, but the details on who it will be remain a mystery

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The federal government has suffered its first major defeat in the Senate, with the Greens and Coalition uniting to reject Labor's centrepiece housing policy.

title.children: Federal government a step closer to early election trigger as Senate rejects housing bill

image.altText: Kitchen Hut, Cradle Mountain, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: An injured Victorian bushwalker survives a night in the freezing Tasmanian wilderness sheltering in a 113-year-old hut near the Overland Track, as authorities urge adventurers to reconsider travel in the area.

title.children: Injured Victorian bushwalker rescued on Tasmania's Overland Track

image.altText: Aleh Sidorchyk smokes a cigarette as he walks out of the Adelaide city police watch house.

items.synopsis: Belarusian actor Aleh Sidorchyk is fined $750 but has avoided jail, after he inappropriately touched a female passenger several times on a Malaysia Airlines flight to Australia in February ahead of this year's Adelaide Festival.

title.children: Actor who indecently touched female passenger on flight to Australia fined $750 but not jailed

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios serves against Daniil Medvedev at the Montreal Masters tennis tournament.

items.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios has pulled out of the grass-court tournament in Halle with a knee injury, but says he still hopes to be fit to play Wimbledon.

title.children: Nick Kyrgios out of Halle with knee injury but still hopes to play Wimbledon

image.altText: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken shakes hands with Chinese President Xi Jinping

items.synopsis: The United States and China pledge to mend their badly deteriorated ties during a critical visit to Beijing by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, who met with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

title.children: US and China pledge to stabilise deteriorating ties and resume high-level talks

image.altText: Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah salutes, wearing a decorated military uniform and cap. He has a large red ring on his right hand.

items.synopsis: Brunei's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah meets with Anthony Albanese to reaffirm their nations' cooperation on a range of issues, despite past concerns over the sultanate's human rights record.

title.children: The Sultan of Brunei and Anthony Albanese meet to discuss renewed partnership

image.altText: A slightly blurry photo shows hundreds of people crammed onto the deck of a blue fishing boat in the ocean.

items.synopsis: Pakistani authorities arrest 14 suspects responsible for the alleged trafficking of several migrants who drowned after their boat capsized in the sea off Greece.

title.children: Suspects arrested in Pakistan over Greece boat disaster

image.altText: An AFL player eyes the football he holds in one hand as he prepares to kick.

items.synopsis: Hawthorn will be without captain James Sicily for their next three AFL matches after his appeal against a suspension for rough conduct was rejected.

title.children: Hawks skipper James Sicily fails in AFL suspension appeal

image.altText: A cloud of smoke rises in Jenin, the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

items.synopsis: The Israeli military said it launched the raid in Jenin to detain Palestinians suspected of carrying out attacks.

title.children: Three Palestinians killed in fierce clash with Israeli troops in the occupied West Bank

image.altText: An Indigenous girl with her face dyed all black wearing a colourful feathered headband.

items.synopsis: In a 280,000-hectare triangle of preserved Amazon rainforest, Indigenous communities hope for "total eviction" of non-Indigenous settlers.

title.children: In an increasingly threatened rainforest, Indigenous teens carry out a rite of passage
